page.title: 16BRASTED CHART
page.content: The land of the Chart has been owned by a succession of families. Brasted people had rights of the common to graze cattle and pigs, gather peat and firewood. In the Domesday book of 1086 the manor of Brasted was recorded as having "Wood for pannage for 20 hogs" (i.e. 20 pigs were allowed to forage.) Although used a lot, the land has probably never been ploughed. The hill must have been much less wooded when it was a common. Now it is a wooded area where you can see many different types of woodland birds such as the robin, blackbird and wood pigeon. There are many kinds of plants in the Chart and the hilltop beechwood is an ideal place for walking.
